reviewText:
Sonic CD is a 2D platformer that has you as a hedgehog finding your way through labyrinth like levels. Between getting from the start to the finish of the level, Sonic can collect rings. These rings are insurance. If you get hit with rings, they all spray out of the hedgehog. If you get hit without any rings, Sonic dies and its back to the last checkpoint. If you have 50 rings at the end of the level, you can jump up into a giant ring that lets you do a bonus stage for a chance to get a chaos emerald. The bonus stage feels like Sega's version of Sonic running around a Mario Kart track. After every 2 levels comes a boss level that has you stock up on rings or lives before you face the boss Robotnik. The game breezed by in a few hours without me noticing.

For those that haven't played any Sonic games from the 90s, the controls are simple enough to use one button. That one button is jump if you're standing or running. If you're ducking and push the button it charges up a spinball. When you release the down direction, Sonic will fire off with a super boost of speed. If you press down while running, Sonic tucks into a ball that will damage enemies.

The real gimmick of Sonic CD is the ability to go into the past or future. You do this by first hitting a sign and then going so fast that you will either go to the era. It feels like nothing more than a pallet swap. There are changes here and there, but you won't need to visit one era or another to progress. Plus there is a screen that takes Sonic to the era and it stops the gameplay. There's not that much variety in gameplay. Even the brief water levels only slow down Sonic, forcing you to find air bubbles to breathe. He can't swim or anything.

For the explorers out there, jumping between past, present and future will reveal secrets. Visit the past to improve the future. When you make two levels have good futures, the third level will take place in the good future. Without the exploration, every level goes by after a few minutes.

New to the series is a Metal Sonic who kidnaps Amy shortly into the game. At some point you will need to race Metal Sonic to get her back. It adds to the unique boss fights. The boss battles are what make the game stand out from other old school Sonic games. You need to defeat each Robotnik boss in different ways other than the traditional 'hit him.' Some you'll need to run fast while dodging objects. Others you'll need to go up on hovering rocks and still others involve chasing him.

Since the game came out between Sonic 2 and 3 there are only a few items to find in boxes. Items like extra lives, 10 extra rings, super fast shoes, temporary invincibility and a shield barrier that lets Sonic take an extra hit. There is nothing new that you won't find in the first two Sonic games.

Unique to the Sonic CD is an animated cartoon introduction and then another when you beat the game, before and as credits roll. Both are nice to look at and pretty brief. They add some much needed flair outside the game to make it feel different from the other old school Sonic games. Sonic CD shouldn't take more than 3 hours to complete. Once you complete the game, it unlocks Tails as a playable character. Tails is a fox that plays the same as Sonic, but if you tap the jump button in mid air, Tails can helicopter around for a while. I can understand why he is an unlockable character, because with him it becomes far too easy to just hover over entire levels.

The game feels easy up until a point, which lets new players get far into the game before it gets challenging.  To add to how easy the game is, if you use all your lives, you start at the same level you were at, instead of restarting the zone. The backgrounds are beautiful and have a lot going on. The levels feel large enough to get lost in. The real challenge is traversal, because the enemies are quite forgettable. Sonic will be bouncing off of springs, doing loops, running up ramps, zooming through tubes, running against treadmills, avoiding crushing blocks, hopping on enemies, running around what I can only call gears, but they're not and much more. It didn't feel to me like there were many moments for Sonic to get up to top speed.

Even with the future and past dynamic, the game feels like a big sidestep from Sonic 2. There is nothing new here, but is that a bad thing?

reviewText:
Ah, Sonic CD. Arguably one of the only games worth owning on the ill-fated Sega CD, this title takes the classic Sonic formula of high-speed, momentum-based platforming and adds time travel to the mix, and this is the feature that will make or break the game for you. Scattered throughout the levels are signposts with 'past' and 'future' written on them. Running past one of the signs, then building up enough speed, will send Sonic backwards or forwards in time. Each level actualy has four variations: the past, the present, and the good and bad futures. This generaly works well (although I did get once stuck in a wall after warping to the past), with the differences in layout between the time periods providing for some interesting platforming, and adds to the game's greater focus on exploration.
In each Zone (called Acts in other Sonic games) there are two objects to destroy in the past: Eggman's robot generators, and Metal Sonic holigram projectors. Destroying the projectors results in animals roaming about the Zone, to no effect whatsoever. However, destroying a generator will result in all enemies in the Zone instantly being destroyed, as well as changing the future. You see, if you travel to the future normaly, it's a corupted wastland, a bad future. By destroying the generators, you can alter the future, creating the harmonious good futures instead. However, this only applies to the first and second Zones of each Round (called Zones in other Sonic games). In the 3rd Zone of each Round you start in the future; if you destroyed the generator in both other Zones, this will be a good future, and if not, a bad future. Locating the generators can be quite tricky, due to the non-linear, multi-level stage design, and the Zones in this game can be hard to navigate. In addition to all that, to get the game's true ending, you have to make good futures in every single Zone. Or, instead, you could get 50 rings during a Zone, reach the signpost, and enter 3D, UFO-Smashing special stage to collect the Time Stones. Getting all 7 will automaticly get you a good future in every zone, and and guarantee you the good ending.
This is where the game's main problem rears it's ugly head: It claims to have a focus on exploration, but there's really no point to actualy exploring. Getting the Time Stones is so much easier then smashing every single generator, and once you have them, the level design can seem like more of a hinderence then anything. Worse, if you don't care about geting the good ending, and just want to play this like any other clasic sonic game, you might find the level design to be an outright hindrance, with few places to pick up and keep speed. Whether you find the level design to be a blessing (huge, beautiful stages, full of interesting gimmicks) or a curse (massive, mazelike, slow hells) will depend mostly on your playstyle, and is almost entirely subjective.
On a more positive note, this game looks realy good. The game's been updated with 16:9 widescreen support, and you can use one of various filters if you wish to. The game also sounds great, with both the US and JP/EU soundtracks being available to choose from. Each version is great, and having them both is absolutely fantastic. As this is an updated rerelease of the game, various improvements have been made, including tweeked collision detection in both the main game and the special stages, the above-mentioned dual soundtracks and widescreen support, and Tails as a playable character, unlocked after beating the game with Sonic.
Although level design may be subpar for some, Sonic CD is still a good game with a lot to offer, and if you enjoy hunting for secrets, the game has you covered with large levels, each possessing four variants, and lots of little touches that fun to find. Having exploration as it's main focus, rather than being secondary to speedy platforming, may make it the black sheep of the Genesis titles, but the game still nails the smooth platforming that defines classic Sonic. This version is without a doubt the best way to experience Sonic CD, and for just $5, I'd definitely reccomend this game.

In my opinion, this game is certainly the best game in the 2D sonic series, I might go as far to say the best game in the franchise. Whilst a lot of people will say this game is overrated and isn't as good as games like Sonic 2 or Sonic 3 & Knuckles, I beg to differ.

Sonic CD is your normal every-day side scroller with our favorite blue hedgehog, whilst a lot of people think this game didn't bring as many new things to the table as it could have, it brought in great new features with the inclusion of Past and Future signs. Once you run into one of these signs, you'll have to keep your momentum and run for a certain period of time. If you lose speed or hit an obstacle you'll lose this ability. But if you keep up your speed, you'll be transported to a Past/Future orientation of the current stage. The past orientations usually show the stage at a much better time, with greenery and a serene atmosphere, a lot nicer in contrast to the future versions of the stage which either look chaotic, rusted or dull and overrun with machinery. Along the game you'll run into collapsed robot transporters, if you go back in the past of the level and return to them you can break them, resulting in a good future for the stage, if you go all the way to the future in the current stage you'll be greeted with a Good Future rendition of the stage, the Good Future's are like the Bad Futures in terms of the technology, but they look a lot more wonderful and are all generally amazing to go through.

An alternate way to get all the good futures (And the good ending) Is to collect all the time stones by finishing the stage with 50 rings and jumping into the giant ring at the end. This will transport you to the special stages of the game. Which compared to the other 2D sonic games, are very unique. They take place in a 3D enviroment in which sonic has to jump and destroy UFO's to complete the stage, it may sound simple but the stages are usually surrounded in water. If sonic lands in the water, 10 seconds are lost instantly making it very hard at times, especially in the last two stages. Whilst I find the controls to be sluggish, these stages are certainly the most unique in the sonic series.


Aside from the tenses in this game, it also presents something new in the sonic series, it posesses 2 sountracks which can be accessed in the steam version. Whilst I believe the US soundtrack has the best tracks, the Japanese soundtrack also has some of the best music, it also contains one of the most iconic themes in the sonic series, the Stardust Speedway Bad Future track.

All in all, I would definitely recommend this game to fans of the sonic series, I'd recommend it to anyone in general. 10/10 from me.

reviewText:
A good example of what the Mega CD could do if given the proper consideration.
For the longest time Sonic CD was my #1 favourite video game; a title possessed of a rare quality for the time it was released.

Developed as a showpiece for CD-ROM technology, it was hoped that Sonic CD would pave the way for a new generation of quality disc-based games and whilst it is a fine title in its own right, ultimately the grand vision never materialized like Sega once hoped.

Sonic CD appealed to me as a youngster for its sharp 2D graphics and flourishes of 3D, for its excellent soundtrack (in the European/Japanese version at least) and its robust palette of different levels.

Sharing much in common with the first game in the series, this lesser-known title in Sonic's library consists of 7 different stages interwoven with the theme of time travel. When Sonic passes certain posts in the game world he gains the ability to transport himself through time by gaining enough speed for several seconds (an obvious inspiration from Back to the Future).

Each stage features a design for the current time period (whether it's a good/bad future, present or the past) complete with new colours, different enemy patterns and an alternate arrangement of both the level layout and music. Such variety for a game released in 1993 is stunning (as each level essentially comes in four flavours) and it helps set Sonic CD apart from the generally lacklustre titles that call the Sega Mega CD console home.

Although the method of time travel is clunky, it remains an interesting mechanic and part of the game's advanced challenge as the only way to secure a truly good ending is to visit levels in the past and destroy a robot-producing factory present in each one.

When you add in an impressive 3D bonus stage, a time attack mode and other unlockables that save to your console's internal memory; you've got a truly great Mega CD title that keeps very small company.

This HD remaster on Steam was helmed by wizard programmer Christian Whitehead and is the best way to experience Sonic CD today, and after many years the game is finally reaching the larger audience it deserved on current generation consoles and mobile devices.

The time this game spent as my #1 video game was time admittedly obstructed by nostalgia, as very few people I spoke to then had any knowledge of this special game at all; making the whole thing feel like a more personal experience than usual.

The gameplay isn't as fast or exciting as Sonic the Hedgehog 2, the challenge is a bit lax and the overall level design does leave a lot to be desired.

But Sonic CD is still a good game and it's one that has aged remarkbly well thanks to this gorgeous HD remaster.

PROS: This is one of the most solid ports I've ever seen; Text file/Instruction manual info, -both- the JP/EU soundtrack options, other gameplay modes. Around here is where they began to lose the idea of what made Sonic flow so well in previous games, and that's really bad for the time travel system that requires you to reach and maintain max speed. Motion-sickness is also pretty bad for this one since they began to explore vertical worlds.

OVERALL: Many would say this is the best 2D sonic to date. Others would say it's one of the worst of the series. The game has its flaws, but has great traditionally-animated cutscenes and beautiful levels. If you like Sonic, it's worth a shot-- You'll at least walk away with an absolutely amazing soundtrack.

SCORE: 8/10

This is an amazing remake of a fantastic Sega CD game. A classic reborn with HD visuals, 16:9 Widescreen, and Acheivments! This game also introduced a bunch of new concepts, and is the game that introduced Metal Sonic and Amy Rose!

Plot - 8.0

Same old, same old. Dr. Robotnik is up to no good and you have to stop him. Dr. Robotnik chained Little Planet to the side of a mountain, and Amy Rose gets kidnapped by Metal Sonic. So basically, you have to go and unchain Little Planet and rescue Amy Rose.

Gameplay - 9.5

The gameplay in this game is fantastic, and I actually liked the Super Peel-Out, a new move introduced in the Sega CD version of this game. The Super Peel-Out, if charged enough, will make Sonic blast off with a burst of speed, however, Sonic is vunerable during a Super Peel-Out. The Super Peel-Out aside, I really liked the Time Travelling concept. To Time Travel, touch a sign marked Future or Past, then run fast enough without stopping for enough time and you will be sent to the Past or Future, depending on which sign you touched. A neat little new thing was added in Sonic CD, Robot Teleporters. These can only be found in the past, and when destroyed, all badniks will explode, thus ridding that level of all of it's badniks. Other then all those new gameplay mechanics, the gameplay is what you would expect from your average Sonic game on a CD. By the way, Special Stages are torture. You run around a 3D field destroying UFOs. But there's a time limit, which makes the Special Stages so much harder then they need to be. Completing a Special Stage rewards you with a Time Stone. Collecting all seven Time Stones rewards you with the Good Ending. However, not getting all seven gets you the Bad Ending.

Graphics - 8.0

Okay, I'm not going to be too harsh on the graphics, this IS a remake, after all. There are three differant filters you can choose from. Nostalgic, which is pretty much the graphics from the original, but touched up so the screen isn't a blurry mess. Smooth, which smoothens the graphics so everything looks less pixelated, but all it really does is make the screen blurry. And the last available filter, Sharp, which pretty much makes the edges of pixels look REALLY pointy.The filters aside, the colors in the game are vibrant and my eyes love looking at the stages. Well, some of them. Some stages have bland colors, like Metallic Madness Present, and Wacky Workbench. Other then some bland colors, this game is pure eye candy.

Level Design - 7.0

The level design in this game isn't exactly the best, but is half decent. I give it a 7 because Spikes and Badniks are placed in the most trolling places. And seriously, why are there so many Badniks? There are way too many Badniks in most of the levels, and the level design can easily frustrate you.

Soundtrack - 10.0

The soundtrack of this game is downright amazing. There are two soundtracks to choose from - the JP/EU soundtrack or the US soundtrack. I personally prefer the JP/EU soundtrack, but both are fantastic. The JP/EU soundtrack seems to be going for an Electronic feel, while the US soundtrack seems to be going for a Rock feel. Unfortunately, the producer of the JP/EU Intro and Ending theme had passed, so the developers could't obtain rights to use the lyrics for the Intro theme and the Ending theme. In other words, the music is there, but the lyrics aren't. I'm not going to lower the score because of this, since the developers didn't really have much of a choice.

Overall Score - 8.0

Don't get me wrong, this is a great remake of the 1993 classic, but it definitly could be better.

Outdoes the original in every aspect, especially the physics. After playing the Megadrive CD version last week, I figured I'd have to rehash my recommendation. Sonic CD features gameplay very similiar to Sonic 2, with slight changes to the spindash (reversible to S2 standards in the new port), and a time traveling mechanic. At certain points of the level, there are signposts that start a time traveling sequence you trigger by simply going fast. This will either make you go into the Future, or the Past. Each Level has 4 different versions of itself. A Present version, a Bad Future version (representing the bad guy winning), a Good Future version (representing Sonic stopping him), and a Past version, where you have to travel to in order to save the future. While this is a straightforward Sonic platformer in the quaint essence, it has a good variety of exploration as levels are laid out to be two-directional, which is necessary in this game as you have to sometimes go back in a level after you traveled to the Past in order to prevent Robotnik taking the area over, and as you might think, there are multiple endings reflecting your actions or lack of it. It's was a fantastic game back then, and still is nowadays, and the added widescreen support, new engine that fixes physics woes, the option to play as Tails as well as being able to choose the soundtrack wrap this well up as something you should definitely not miss having played if you are a platformer enthusiast, as being back as Sonic enthusiast since Generations, I can say it's definitely the franchise's best.

Sonic CD earns its place among the greats of the Sonic franchise with solid level design, an interesting gimmick, and a great soundtrack. Its gimmick, time travel, offers an incentive to explore and map out the levels themselves, as well as providing opportunities for many little differences within single levels. The roboticizers and the holograms, which can be seen in both the past and the present, but can only be dealt with in the past, give a goal when hunting about the level. Destroying them rids the level of all enemies thus making it safe, or safer anyway, to go as fast as you please. The bonus stages offer up a new experience while being similar enough to the main game in concept to avoid breaking your rhythm. The cinematic at the start and the finish of the game frame it with a context and a healthy helping of Sonic Boom, a track that I just can't help but enjoy. The ending cinematic especially does a great job of releasing the tension built up throughout the game and leaving you thinking about all the exciting parts instead of those enemies that were made just to slow you down or the way Sonic seems to slip around like his sneakers are made of greasy bacon.

I've enjoyed this game enough to complete multiple times on multiple systems. It's level designs are not as streamlined and fast as Sonic 2, but it controlls just as well and the option of hunting down Robotnik's robotisizers for the good ending instead of getting all the Time Stones (this games Chaos Emeralds) offers some nice variety for a 2d Sonic title.
Sanic's deep and multi-layered character compellingly contextualizes the rest of the experience, making it truly memorable.

Sonic CD is an outstanding game, though because it was on the SegaCD, not many people knew about it.

Sonic CD earns its place among the greats of the Sonic franchise with solid level design, an interesting gimmick, and a great soundtrack. Its gimmick, time travel, offers an incentive to explore and map out the levels themselves, as well as providing opportunities for many little differences within single levels. The roboticizers and the holograms, which can be seen in both the past and the present, but can only be dealt with in the past, give a goal when hunting about the level. Destroying them rids the level of all enemies thus making it safe, or safer anyway, to go as fast as you please. The bonus stages offer up a new experience while being similar enough to the main game in concept to avoid breaking your rhythm. The cinematic at the start and the finish of the game frame it with a context and a healthy helping of Sonic Boom, a track that I just can't help but enjoy. The ending cinematic especially does a great job of releasing the tension built up throughout the game and leaving you thinking about all the exciting parts instead of those enemies that were made just to slow you down or the way Sonic seems to slip around like his sneakers are made of greasy bacon.
A very unique Sonic game, and arguably the best. The soundtrack is probably my absolute favourite thing about it.

Alongside Sonic 3, this would be the go-to example of what makes a Sonic game- Sonic CD, for a game made roughly 20 years ago, feels like it was made yesterday, with it's beautiful visuals, amazing sountracks, and smooth gameplay, any platformer fan would be insane to ever skip this one over.If there ever were a truer example of why Sonic isn't all about speed, I can't find one. Sonic CD gives you speed as a tool to meet your ends, but it heavily discourages it in favour of precision, thought, and exploration, while it still feels faster than your average platformer.

One of the most fun elements of Sonic CD is it's integration of time travel into the core gameplay, whether it's simply seeing what each beautifully designed level looks like in each of the four different timelines, or to find all the different objectives this non-standard Sonic platformer has to offer.
If you want to get the most enjoyment out of this game, take some time to explore each timeline in each area. Take a look at the bleak, dark bad futures, then go back into the past and destroy Eggman's machines so that you can create a good future, all while admiring the thematic changes in music and art that come with each timeline.

Sure, the game's design can be headache-inducing at times, but it's a short adventure that will leave you with some fond memories, and it'll certainly make you want to listen to those soundtracks over and over again. Plus, the animated cutscenes and multiple endings are a nice bonus.

Honestly, if any Sonic game needs a spiritual sequel, it's this one! Time travel is a simple yet very interesting and game-changing concept. And unlike the recent Sonic Boom titles, exploration and nonlinearity in this game feels RIGHT. it's a damn shame this game was on a system that was all but a failure, but thanks to the power of remastering, we are here able to play it in glorious HD. Do yourself a favour and pick this game up, I have a feeling you'll like it.

reviewText: The finest Sonic the Hedgehog game of the 16-bit era, with a ton of improvements. This is NOT an emulation. It's a fully-fledged port. Buy it.

Sonic CD is a platformer game starring famous hedgehog from Sega and was originally released for Sega CD in 1993, making use of CD technology. And having two different soundtracks for JP or US region. It was later released for PC, having improved intro and ending movies, without limits of Sega CD. And now it was rereleased and improved for smartphones, PS3, Xbox360 and Steam.

What's new in remastered version? It was ported onto new engine, allowing new menues, small stuff and even support of widescreen. It kept full movies from PC version. It even used rotation and scaling where it made sense, where Sega CD used choppy animation. And it even added new content, with ability to choose preference of Spin Dash from Sonic 2, ability to choose US or JP soundtrack, leaderboards (for your time attack fun too), achievements and even ability to select the ever cute Tails the Fox, that wasn't originally in Sonic CD. You have to beat game once to unlock him and even has ability to fly from Sonic 3 too. Lacks intro and ending movies though. Yes, he got new animation frames.
The only bad thing I can think of is that Japanese soundtack main songs lack lyrics, instead replaced with custom-made instrumentals. They lack some of charm.

Now, if you have to descripe Sonic CD in one line: it's Sonic 1, but more gimmicky and easier.
And it's not a bad thing, since Sonic 1, like most classic Sonic games, was one of the better pure-platformers out there (I mean, no attack button or such). With more movement-based awesome physics, both while running or rolling, simple control, nice pacing and multiple branches, it was great. It also had unique rings-health system, where you would survive a hit as long as you had at least one ring, while scattering them all around.
Sonic CD retains most of the greatness, and despite being released after Sonic 2, got the looks and control feels of the first part. Background look much more complex and game uses CD audio, which may not sound chiptune-like, but still has great tune to it. Japan version at least. US soundtrack is more of generic thing, with some dark tones here and there.

Sonic have to travel onto the flying little planet, which has time-teleport troubles and is controlled by Eggman, just to kick his egg butt once again. Oh, and to save planet. And Amy. And battle with Metal Sonic. Your mission is still same, to get to the end of the level, each of 7 levels having 3 acts, the third one being a boss act.
Bosses are one-trick ponies. They are easy, but have some gimmick going on for them. While other Sonic games have more of classic challenging bosses, each taking 8 hits, Sonic CD ones use various trickish mechanics, giving them a wackier cartoonish feel. For example, one of the bosses requires Sonic to keep running over conveyer belt of sorts, speeding it up and making friction melt the bottom part of Eggman's machine.
And bad sides, once again, bosses are too easy once you know what to do. Or even if you don't. Final boss isn't that much of problem either, as you can just rush him down with the forgiving ring-health system of Sonic games.

You will also notice that level design is all over the place. It doesn't feel tight or much of challenge, instead being more of easy maze, having unneded branches and areas. And for sure you will notice Past and Future signs. Well, why, it's yet another gimmicky approach to game design, the Time Travel!
Once you pass over time travel sign, you will get ability to teleport either into Past or Future if you will be able to keep maximum speed for more than few seconds. This will make you learn the level layout, either to find the best cleanest path or to just abuse some springs that will send you into loop. The main difference between Past or Future is level layout and visual theme being slightly altered. It's not really a big deal.
But in the Past is where you can find two important objects: Flying engine destroying which will kill all the enemies in the act and will turn Bad Future into Good Future, while destroying Metal Sonic hologram will make animals appear in the level again. If you destroy all engines in all levels, you will get good ending. Hard work!
There is little reason to visit Future though.
But bad thing is, such exploration for Past and engine still negatively affects level design when player just wants to beat them in traditional way. Time Travel barely adds anything to the gameplay, because by time you would go to Past to destroy all enemies, you could easily beat the level. And if you are aiming for good ending, then there is actually even easier way to get it: Collect all Time Stones from Special Stages! Once you collect all time stones, you will get Good Future in all levels from that point and you will always have good ending, making time travel obsolote.
Thankfully, modern version gives you a special achievement for doing all hard Time Travel work, giving at least some reason to do it at least once.

Oh. And Special Stages, that you get by having 50 rings by the end of stage, are awesome in this one. Using a trick similiar to Mode-7 kart games on SNES, you control Sonic on 3D flat track, who has to jump and crush down every UFO that patrol around, under time limit. Running over water will deplete timer quickly and a special UFO will appear that gives time bonus once you have only 20 seconds left. This is my favourite Special/Bonus Stage of all Sonic games, it really is fun to control.
And yes, this remaster upgraded special stages visuals greatly. Instead of having choppy pre-made animations frames for UFO enlarging as you come closer to them game now uses real smooth scaling for them. It allows you to measure just how close you are to them so much better.

Sonic CD is still fun platformer. But it's too easy to feel much of accomplishment and gimmicks are distractive game design. Time Travel feels unneeded and tackled on, but there are people who actually like this Past-searching quest. Some people dislike this game, others call it the best. I say, go for it, try it, you may love it.
It got old Sonic charm at least.

reviewText: One of the best examples of level design, 2D or 3D, that I can think of.  Way ahead of its time, when I think about it.  Looking at any point of any level, there are usually at least 3 routes running parallel that you could be taking.  Perfect balance, in my opinion, of speed and precision platforming; the game lets you run as fast as you like through certain sections, while others require reactions, timing and control.  While the latter sections may be somewhat challenging, none of them are infuriatingly difficult and you're unlikely to find yourself stuck at one section for any length of time.  The Past/Future mechanic is brilliant; switching between times changes the level around a bit to make it harder or easier in certain places, and this can be used to your advantage but only if you are able to build up enough speed to travel in time.  It adds an extra dimension to speedruns, and multiplies the already huge amount of ways to beat a level.  Boss fights are short, sweet and creative, varying hugely each time.  As for the port itself, it's a great port; about the best I could hope for.  There's a main menu and a save system that has up to 4 save slots.  There's proper audio options, you can use the old spin dash animation if you like, and you can apply a Sharp, Smooth or Nostalgic (i.e. classic) video filter.  It appears to be pretty happy running in Windows, no bugs that I've found and alt-tabbing brings up no issues.\nOverall, no real gripes besides the lack of story.

reviewText:
Sonic CD Review
More than just a classic action game, Sonic CD is an exemplary port of a retro game to a modern platform.

History has not been kind to the Sega CD add-on, which has largely been regarded as a failure. Still, the console did have several excellent exclusives, among which was an ambitious time-hopping adventure in its most popular franchise. Sonic CD was one of the games that made a Sega CD worth owning. While its cartridge-based brothers saw frequent rereleases, Sonic CD's reissues on the PC and GameCube (via the Sonic Gems Collection) were clunky and inaccurate, as well as missing features. So it is with great celebration among Sonic series fans that Sega has rereleased Sonic CD on modern platforms as a download game, but what makes it even sweeter is the care and effort that has gone into the conversion.

Time travel in Sonic's world is so quotidian that they post it on street signs.
Sonic CD is very much a game in the classic Sonic vein. As Sonic, you run, spin, and jump around colorful, themed areas; you collect rings, smash enemies, and interact with varied environmental gimmicks. Whereas Sonic 2 and Sonic 3 favored more open stages with lots of speed-boosting contraptions, Sonic CD's stages reflect the more cluttered feel of the original game, with elaborately designed backgrounds and decorations littering the landscape. It's incredibly difficult to simply speed directly through a level in Sonic CD because various traps, enemies, and deviously placed obstacles can send a careless hedgehog reeling.

This approach to stage design has its advantages because Sonic CD is laden with odd little one-off gimmicks and hidden surprises (see if you can find the hidden goddess statue--it even gives you an achievement!). It also influences the overall stage design in interesting ways: Collision Chaos is filled with more high-speed springs and bumpers than any other Sonic zone, while Metallic Madness is a maze that can loop endlessly if you don't pay attention to where you go. Some of the stages, however, have experimental elements that prove to be more frustrating than fun. The much-despised Wacky Workbench level features a magnetized floor that sends Sonic soaring up to the stage's ceiling at the slightest touch, which practically destroys his ability to run for long distances.

In fact, running long distances anywhere in Sonic CD is quite challenging, but there's a design reason behind it. Sonic CD's major selling point in its day was its time-travel feature, which greatly increased the size and scope of the game. Each stage has four variations: a past, present, a good future, and a bad future. And each one has different graphics, music, stage elements, and designs. Travelling through time is accomplished by touching a specially marked Past" or "Future" signpost and then keeping up a consistent high speed for about five seconds to initiate a time warp. This is often easier said than done. Though some stages have areas well suited to time travel

My expectations were met. The game is a fun ride through and through; but it has has some questionable design choices that I feel drag it down.

The gameplay is exactly what you'd expect from a classic sonic game. And to it's benefit, Sonic CD is more inspired than most of the other sonic games. When you step into a level,  you quickly come to understand the depth on display here. There are essentially three different phases for every one stage; meaning you can flip through different pallets and scenery by hitting a post and going fast. While this does wonders to help keep the game interesting, the real opportunities to flip the phase are limited unless you are clairvoyant or unreasonably reckless. In a game about going fast, Sonic CD seems to want to slow you down quite often, which is an issue.

What's also an issue is some downright bizzare boss and game over music. A slowed down, pitch shifted version of a laugh accompanies a creepy tone. It's abundantly clear that this is supposed to be Dr. Robotnik laughing at us. The game plays this theme every time you see him. And I get that the point of the game is to stop him, but really? You couldnt've picked a less jarring theme for boss fights? This, compounded with the fact that Dr. Robotnik is seriously out of good ideas, as most bosses can be beaten by slapfighting them, turns bossfights into a chore.

It's good, but just barely so.

reviewText:
(I know my play time is really short, but I've played this game quite a bit on Sonic Gems Collection, so bear with me)

I never really understood why so many people held Sonic CD in such high regard. I don't think it's the best Sonic game, and I don't even think it was the best game on the Sega CD (that honor would go to the Lunar games).

It's not a bad game at all, but I don't think it holds a candle to Sonic 2 or even Sonic 3 and Knuckles. My biggest beef with this game is the level design- it's labyrinthine and maze-like when compared to the more straightforward levels of other 2D Sonic games. It's hard to go fast in a Sonic game when the levels are filled with more platforms and speed bumps. This becomes more problematic when you factor in the time warping mechanic, which requires you to maintain a high speed after passing a warp post. I can definitely appreciate the ambition the developers had when making this game- the time travel system gives you more levels to explore, and there's nothing wrong with that- but it can be frustrating at times when it seems like the levels are designed against the principle of going fast.

Like I said, though, this game is not terrible. The level design might be a little too weird for a game about going really fast, but if you want a challenge, look no further. This game's levels are long and complex, but they don't feel padded out at all. They deliver a unique kind of gameplay challenge that I don't think can be matched by any other Sonic game. It's unique, and I can definitely appreciate a game that dares to be different. You kind of have to change your playing style and be more methodical to really get the most out of Sonic CD.

Also, both soundtracks for this game are absolutely phenomenal. For those that don't know, the American and Japanese versions of this game had completely different soundtracks. The Japanese version had a pretty straightforward, Sonic-like soundtrack with plenty of catchy and upbeat songs, while the 'Murican release had a more unique score inspired by 90's rock, hip-hop and industrial music. The music buff in me really likes the American release, but whichever one you end up playing with, they both fit the game really well.

All in all, I still think Sonic CD is a great game despite its flaws. And for the low price of $5, you really can't go wrong. This game used to be much harder to get a hold of due to the limited market of the Sega CD, and the original PC release being a nightmare to run on modern machines, so having this HD re-release with both soundtracks is a huge treat.

reviewText:
If you want my full thoughts on Sonic CD, you can listen to my review on Game Hoard Podcast[soundcloud.com] (Review itself starts at 18:12)

Sonic is a character that I grew up loving. I had a Sega Genesis as a child and played tons of Sonic 2 and Sonic 3 & Knuckles. At the time, I had no idea that the Sega CD existed, so I completely missed out on Sonic CD. Now, years later, I received Sonic CD in the Sonic Games Collection and excitedly sat down to play what I thought would be a nostalgia-filled romp in a franchise I once loved. Perhaps I've moved on from Sonic or maybe Sonic CD isn't the best example of a classic Sonic game, because I found the experience baffling at best and infuriating at worst.

Gameplay
Well, the game certainly moves fast, which no doubt was part of the marketing. Unfortunately, fast =/= fun. The game lacks a good sense of momentum. Sonic often goes from a complete stand still to flying across the screen, and vice versa, with no inbetween. This means that you feel very little control over the game at many parts and more often than not the game launches you into a death trap. Often these are unavoidable because the camera does not keep Sonic centered on the screen and you cannot see what is coming up and react to it. It's just poor design for a platformer and leads to a lot of frustration.

Also strange is the time travel aspect. I love time travel as a story conceit and as a gameplay mechanic but it's completely pointless here. The past and future versions of the level are nearly identical and destroying the robot machine in the past only effects the zone you are in. It's completely optional; you can literally beat the game without ever once time traveling. There are no puzzles based around the mechanic and you can get all the time stones without using it. It feels totally tacked on and without purpose.

The pacing of the game is problematic as well. Of the seven zones, only the final two offer any challenge. Most acts can be beated in under a minute, making the game incredibly short and unrewarding. The difficulty spike in the last two stages is simply unreasonable and is where you will spend the vast majority of your time. In particular, the race against Metal Sonic is one of the must unfair, rage-quit inducing sequences I have ever encountered in a game.

Presentation
First off, I love the hand drawn cinematics. Gorgeous, fun, bright. They are what I wanted the game to be. Unfortunately, the game's actual graphics are much less interesting. Unlike other Sonic games where each level has a unique look and setting, all the zones here, including their past and future counterparts, look pretty much the same. Also troubling is that it is often unclear what is an object vs. something in the foreground or background. Something may look like a platform but you'll just fall through it when you try to land on it. Having graphics that clearly convey information to the player is essential for such a fast paced platformer and Sonic CD really let me down in that regard.

Sound design is pretty much what you'd expect, except that there are two different soundtracks. The North American one sounds just like previous Sonic titles but the Japanese one, which is turned on by default, is a bizarre sort of hip-hop fusion that isn't fitting to Sonic at all. Skip to 29:09 in the episode[soundcloud.com] to hear what I mean.

Overall
I simple cannot understand the praise that this game receives. It is far from the strongest title in the Sonic franchise and has major flaws in nearly every part of its design. I can only recommend Sonic CD to those who loved it on the Genesis since it is a very good port. If you haven't played Sonic CD before, I do not recommend giving it a try now.

Sonic CD is a speed-driven platformer with a unique time-traveling mechanic.

This first showed up on the Sega CD. It is one of the best Sonic the Hedgehog games to ever grace a video game system (and I'm being a bit bias there).

The gameplay is typical Sonic the Hedgehog but has a unique twist: time travel. By going through time travel, each level acts differently. Each level has a Past and Future timeline, giving you unique ways to explore each level. What's also cool is the various secrets that you find in each timeline. This is one Sonic game that you can't speed through.

The Special Stages are back but with a slight difference. Instead of collecting rings, you destroying UFOs while running on a square grid. You can run around as much as you want but beware some of the traps laid across the grid.

The PC version has some nice extras such as letting you switch between the Japanese and American soundtracks and much more.

This is a Sonic game that still plays well and stood against the test of time (pun intended). Highly Recommended.

While I never got to play Sonic CD when it was originally released on the Sega CD, I find this particular Sonic game to have always been an underappreciated gem (until now of course).

I find that Sonic CD was overshadowed by Sonic 2 in many ways.  The latter is raved as one of the best Sonic games of all time and has gotten several ports to both other Sega and non-Sega consoles.  Sonic CD had a narrow accessibility for gamers and a pretty shoddy port done for the Gems Collection.  This more or less ensured it would never quite take the limelight like  it deserved.

But it has all come full circle with this multi-platform release that has reinvented a game that, by all means, was and always has been superior to Sonic 2.  It kept the original formula that made the early Sonic games successful, but took up a time travel focus that served to enhance the gameplay in a very compelling way.

Instead of bogging you all down with the technical details, I'll just state the one thing that has stuck with me most prominently.  There are two ways to achieve the good ending, each catering to two different kinds of players: Explorers and speedrunners.  You could even toss aside being classified as either and attempt both approaches, seeing whichever one happens to land you the prize.  It seems like such a small change, but it's the kind of carefully chosen freedom that makes the reward that much more appealing.

Aside from that, you get an actual animated opening and endings, two different soundtracks, an expanded move-set, and a sizable game filled with a variety of interesting locales that  have four distinct looks depending on the time period.  There are also plenty of unlockables, of course.

Find out for yourself why Sonic 2 falls short of this fantastic game.

Game: Sonic CD
Genre: Adventure
Developer: Sonic Team/SEGA
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 83/100
Value Score: 8.3/10

• Story: 7/10
o Sonic CD takes place in separate time zone and possibly a separate reality. Sonic has found out that Dr. Eggman has been playing with time and causing all sorts of issues. With the power of the chaos emeralds, Sonic must travel through time to defeat Eggman and rescue Amy - a new character in the game that is closely related to Sonic.

• Characters: 8/10
o Sonic and Eggman show up in the game just like in any other Sonic game but noticeably missing are Tails and Knuckles who did appear in other Sonic games. For their replacement however two new characters have been added. Amy the pink hedgehog who is in love with Sonic and Metal Sonic a robotic version of the blue hero created by Dr. Eggman to combat Sonic with all and every possible power that Sonic has. Other than that the boss battles most of them are remixes of the older games where you end up fighting Dr. Eggman in his Egg mobile. The enemies are changed somewhat but mainly in appearance as there are several enemies who were recycled in appearance and movement but with minor additions.

• GamePlay: 10/10
o Sonic CD plays like the traditional Sonic game unlike 3D Blast and Pinball. However a few new changes have been added. For one thing a time sign has been added to each and every stage every few areas. These time signs indicate between Past and Future - depending on which one you go through can affect which time you would go in as the name suggests. If you keep running past after check pointing them you will be warped into that specific time. The past usually involves less enemies but more obstacles while the future consists of more open paths but with more enemies. Obtaining the Chaos emeralds is similar to past games and upon capturing all of the emeralds will grant you super Sonic form.

• Graphics: 9/10
o Sonic CD uses a similar visual style as the other 2D sonic games however the details of the locations and of the enemies are far superior to any recent sonic game around its time. Thanks to SEGA CD's upgrade from the genesis, Sonic CD was able to have a bit more texture focus than the other games in the series at the time.

• Sound: 8/10
o Sonic CD uses similar to same sound effects from the older games with a bit better bitrate in quality than the older games again due to the thanks of the power of the Sega CD.

• Music: 10/10
o Sonic CD uses a new set of tracks and tunes for the OST. The soundtrack is very different from the older sonic games bringing it a more exotic feel to it along with the industrial tech backgrounds of the older games.

• Length: 5/10
o Sonic CD is yet again like the other Sonic games despite the fact that one can go different paths thanks to the time zones is still short on the length portion as one can finish the game within 2-3 hours at a quick playthrough. There are seven zones with 2 acts and a third act featuring a direct boss battle. Some of the Zones dont have a third round and could lead you directly to the boss of that zone.

• Replay Value: 6/10
o Sonic CD's replay value allows you to replay each level again in a time challenge - you also have the choice to replay the game through different paths using the time signs but other than that there really isnt much you can do in the game post game wise.

• Player Value: 10/10
o Sonic CD is a great new addition to the 2D Sonic games and undoes every damage that Sonic 3D blast and Spinball did to the series' credibility. Sonic CD brings back the traditional 2D style but brings a visually stunning enhancement and audio thanks to the power of the Sega CD at the time. The game features a bit more of a storyline like Sonic 3 & Knuckles thanks to the addition of the two new characters in the game and the whole time sign/gate aspect is a breath of fresh air introduced in this game.

I may be dating myself here, but I've been playing Sonic games since the first one came with the Sega Genesis. As such, I had no real nostalgia for this game once I got it in the Sonic action pack. It was a brand new experience.

Sonic CD is weird, it's quirky, it's fun, it's cool, and it's still Sonic. There are layers of ideas packed under the Sonic exterior; the levels are designed so that you can either speedrun or explore methodically as Sonic bounces through time. You can either go back in time and destroy Robotnik's badnik generators to produce a good future or just speed through the levels. The game gives you a lot of freedom in that respect, and it also has my favorite special stages out of all the 2D Sonic games.  The soundtrack is funky and the visuals are psychadelic. Sonic CD is like the eccentric cousin to this Genesis brethren. It's a little different, but it's just as viable as an entry into the series.

This first showed up on the Sega CD. It is one of the best Sonic the Hedgehog games to ever grace a video game system (and I'm being a bit bias there).

The gameplay is typical Sonic the Hedgehog but has a unique twist: time travel. By going through time travel, each level acts differently. Each level has a Past and Future timeline, giving you unique ways to explore each level. What's also cool is the various secrets that you find in each timeline. This is one Sonic game that you can't speed through.

The Special Stages are back but with a slight difference. Instead of collecting rings, you destroying UFOs while running on a square grid. You can run around as much as you want but beware some of the traps laid across the grid.

This is a Sonic game that still plays well and stood against the test of time (pun intended). Highly Recommended.

Sonic CD is one of my less favourite classic Sonic games - the level design is the main problem as the game encourages you to go fast (especially with the time travel element), yet punishes you for going fast by having a spike wall right in front of you or something similar. There is often no clear path forward as springs just send you back and the stage having multiple floors just confuse matters. At times the screen is too hard to discern objects from the backgrounds simply because the artists went a bit overboard. Powerup placement is a bit questionable - for example near the first boss is an invincibility box which means there's zero risk of dying.

And yet it's really hard to hate this game. It is ultimately a game that was designed with a lot of love and feels more like a sequel to the first game than Sonic 2 did. For all its faults, it still has a great aesthetic and feels more like a Sonic game than anything in the last 10 years does. The graphics were great at the time and still look good today and the soundtrack holds up just as well.

This version has a nice selection of options including various screen resolutions (including a windowed mode), a few extras, four save slots and achievements. It's pretty good value for money and if you can get it on sale, you're more than likely to get your money's worth out of it. reviewText:
Depending on who you ask, Sonic CD was the best Sonic game ever made. For me, it's difficult to pick the best between this, Sonic 2, or S3&K. They are all excellent and have their own strengths. Sonic CDs strengths are the audio quality thanks to being a Mega CD title, the level design, and the core mechanic of travelling through time, along with the Time Stones instead of the usual Chaos Emeralds.

On a technical level, the sound quality is superior to the Mega Drive Sonic games, however I feel that the tunes are just not as catchy or memorable as the BGM found on the cartridge games. Both the Japanese and Western soundtracks are included with this release on Steam, and while the consensus is that the Japanese soundtrack is great and the Western soundtrack not-so-great, I personally find them both to be rather hit and miss. Both soundtracks definitely have their 'This is a sweet track' and 'lolwtf' moments.

The controls are your standard classic Sonic, movement left, right, up and down, and a jump button. One improvement in this release is you can set the spin dash and peel out moves to work like Sonic 2, 3 and S&K. In those games the instant you let the direction go (down for spin dash, up for peel out) the move was executed. In the original Sonic CD game, there was a warm up period you had to go through before the move actually came out, which made them a bit clunky to use. The game works fine on keyboard, I have not tried with a controller but I'd assume it's fine with that too.

Graphics wise the display has been modified to fit either 16:9 or 16:10 aspect ratio correctly. There are also filters that can be turned on to soften and smooth out the image.

The level (or zone) design is the most colourful and chaotic of the classic Sonic games, with lots of pastel colours in the palette, and a level layout that utilises a lot of vertical space and many different routes to take to get to the end of a zone, making them both pleasing to the eye and lots of fun to play. Both the colour and layout of each zone change when Sonic travels through time, which brings us to the time travel mechanic that's unique to Sonic CD.

Sonic starts each zone in the present time. Scattered around each zone are sign posts that say either 'Past' or 'Future'. After touching one of these sign posts and running at full speed for a few seconds, Sonic will travel to either the past or future, depending on what was written on the last sign post he touched. Both past and future versions of a zone use a unique colour palette, as well as having different layouts. The past is more forgiving in that there are less badniks and obstacles like spikes about, however there are two different possible futures that Sonic can visit.

Initially travelling to a zones future will take Sonic to the zones 'bad future'. There are a lot of badniks roaming about, a lot of traps like spikes and crush traps, the colours are dark and drab, it's generally a very unwelcoming place to be. However, it doesn't have to be this way as Sonic is able to prevent these 'bad futures' by travelling to a zones past and destroying a badnik making machine. Each zone has one of these machines, they can also be found in the present and bad future time periods, but can only be destroyed in the past.

When one of these machines is destroyed, that zones future will become a 'good future'. It also kills all badnik robots in that zone. There are three zones that make up a 'Round'. The third zone of each round is always set in one of the two possible futures, and is where boss battles take place. When both zones one and two have good futures, the third zone is automatically a good future too. However if Sonic fails to make both zones one and two have good futures, the third zone will be set in a bad future.

Reaching the goal post at the end of a zone with 50 or more rings with allow you to access the special stage. It is in these special stages that Sonic can get the Time Stones. The special stages in Sonic CD play similar to Mario Kart on the SNES but in full screen. They are quite tricky to play, as it is difficult to judge distance due to the lack of depth perception of 2D sprite graphics. I can offer some advice with these special stages, you need to jump earlier that you think you do.

Part of the replay value of Sonic CD is trying to make every zone in the game have a good future. Another part is collecting all seven time stones. Like all classic Sonic games, you can beat the game without collecting any of these time stones or making any good futures, but you will not get the 'real ending'.

This is a great game for people who loved the old classic Sonic games and maybe missed out on this one back in the day, due to it being released on the ill fated Mega CD. It plays and looks great, features some of the most creative level design seen in the classic Sonic games, and features the debut of both Amy Rose and Metal Sonic. Tails is also available as a playable character (needs to be unlocked). I recommend this game.

Among the original Sonic games this is the one I find myself returning to the most. The art and music of this game is, in my view, the pinnacle of the original Sonic series. Not only does each stage have three iterations of its music - there are two different soundtracks to choose from (JP is best). Each level presents a good balance between brevity and intricacy, and are a pleasure to go through on subsequent playthroughs.

The time travel mechanic is somewhat awkward to execute, but allows for a multitude of interesting level designs and overall replayability. This aspect of the game is also completely optional. Sonic CD also features one of the more interesting special stage modes, although the faux 3D style is a small step down in terms of visual presentation.

This game does have the usual minor shortcomings found in the series. The bosses are creative, but generally too easy to beat. Most zones present little challenge to get through, although wacky workbench is perhaps the most irritating stage in history. I would say it is a shame this game doesn't seem to have the recognition the mainline sonic games have enjoyed. Updated features and achievements definitely make this one of the best Sonic games to get on Steam. I recommend this game.

As an advant fan of Sonic the Hedgehog for about, all my life I can very well say that Sonic CD is a fantastic game.

However, it is very different from your typical Sonic game. In which, it's a very unique one.

This game (I find) is the darkest in the series. And I don't mean dark as in guns and devilish creatures (Shadow the Hedgehog) or a general dark story (Sonic Adventure 2, Sonic 360).

But it's the presentation that makes this game the darkest.

In this game, you have to find the Time Stones or venture back in time and destroy Eggmans (or Dr. Ivo Robotnik) generators in order to ensure a good future for Little Planet and it's unseen inhabitants.

However, if you fail to do either task, you will ensure a bad future.

A bad future is basically a bad ending. This means Eggman has won; he has ruined all the zones with mechanical machienery. This is evident with the pollution, the evil music (for the US OST anyways..), and overall disgusting look of seeing that nature has been corrupted.

That's why I find it the darkest game in the series (not to mention the creepy images in the sound test.)

Speaking of music, this soundtrack is AMAZING.

There is a common debate over which regional soundtrack is best, as the US s.t. differs from the JP/EU s.t.

I personally LOVE the JP/EU s.t. so much. In fact, I think it may be my favorite Sonic soundtrack ever.

The US one is great as well, it really fits the stages and the boss (threatning music).

While I love a lot of aspects in this game, I do have some problems as well.

One is the level design. I love the level themes, but the execution is..eh. I find that the levels in this game always have some sort of obstacle that stops all momentum. And while that's not bad once in a while, it gets ridicious as the game goes on. One minute you'll be zooming at the speed of sound then BAM! Either an enemy, item capsule, or something stops all that speed. Not to say the other classic sonic games did that, but I feel this one takes the cake in that department.

Another thing I don't care for...the special stages. I don't know if it's just me but I can never seem to get sonic in a good enough position to hit those damn moving ufo's! And not to mention, even when I jump RIGHT next to a blimp, it doesn't count.

I recommend traveling back in time using the posts to get the good ending like I did, because I honestly can't be bothered with those annoying special stages.

Finally, while I love that the bosses in this game are quite (might be some of the most unique bosses in Sonic history honestly), some of these too can get tedious (i'm looking at YOU pinball eggman)


Overall, with a great game, amazing soundtrack, interesting story, and cool levels, Sonic CD is definetly a great Sonic game. Some problems, but still an enjoyable title i'd say.

If I had to rate it, i'd give it a 8.5/10.

Among the original Sonic games this is the one I find myself returning to the most. The art and music of this game is, in my view, the pinnacle of the original Sonic series. Not only does each stage have three iterations of its music - there are two different soundtracks to choose from (JP is best). Each level presents a good balance between brevity and intricacy, and are a pleasure to go through on subsequent playthroughs.

The time travel mechanic is somewhat awkward to execute, but allows for a multitude of interesting level designs and overall replayability. This aspect of the game is also completely optional. Sonic CD also features one of the more interesting special stage modes, although the faux 3D style is a small step down in terms of visual presentation.

This game does have the usual minor shortcomings found in the series. The bosses are creative, but generally too easy to beat. Most zones present little challenge to get through, although wacky workbench is perhaps the most irritating stage in history. I would say it is a shame this game doesn't seem to have the recognition the mainline sonic games have enjoyed. Updated features and achievements definitely make this one of the best Sonic games to get on Steam. I recommend this game.

This is an excellent buy for fans of the Sonic series for many reasons.

Firstly, the Mega Drive/Genesis games remain essential games to this day, but Sonic CD is a lost classic; this is due to it being released exclusively for the Sega CD add-on (which cost a small fortune back in the day, and was largely not worth the time and expense).  For many of the original-era gamers, re-releases such as this are the only way to play original titles and give them the attention they deserve.

But this is not just a re-release!  This version has been enhanced and built upon by fans of the game, and they have not only updated it, they have added new features that arguably elevate this title above the original.  It plays beautifully; a new pkayable character has been added (TAILS!!!) and of course Achievements have been included to bring it up to date.

I only wish the other Sonic games built by the same team could be released on other platforms than the mobile market as they are excellent... but, we can be grateful for this at least.

This isn't a quick-and-dirty port like the other Sonic classics on Steam. This is a remastered re-release, running on a fan-developed engine that runs beautifully, playing whichever of the two soundtracks you prefer.

There's not a lot I can say here that hasn't already been said by Sonic Retro. In short, this is probably the best five dollars you can ever spend on Sonic games.

Retro's full review is here: http://www.sonicretro.org/2011/12/sonic-cd-the-retro-review/

I'd like to think of this release as a sort of gift to the Sonic fan from Sega. Here's an older game that many may have missed. Sega wants fans to remember it because it was a high-quality release from them. They also would like those that missed it to experience one of the best games in the franchise. To miss Sonic CD would be to miss some of the franchise's best (and strangest) level designs. They were really creative with this one. You would also miss the race with Metal Sonic by not playing this game, and that would be a shame.

New? Nah. Improved? In most ways.

First of all, let's coverSonic CD, in general. It's not perfect, but it certainlywas ambitious. Gameplay-wise, it's more like Sonic 1, which speed-demons tend to not like. it's more based on exploration than anything else. The levels are large and you may get lost in a few, but it's actually disapoinintly easy (especially the bosses, despite being some of the most creative and interesting ones in the series), though the replay value makes up for that. This is considered the best Sonic game by many, and for good reason. Definiteltly not good for a first Sonic game, though. Stick with Sonic 3 & Knuckles for that.

If that sounds good to you, it's a good buy. this is probably the best version of Sonic CD overall-and likely the cheapest you'll find, at 5 bucks normally. If you own the original or any of the ports, you could skip this one and not miss much. Read on for details.

It was hard to get used to after playing the original for over a decade, personally. This is also the first time, to my knowledge, the first time JP/EU soundtrack is available inside the US officially, which is something many fans have wanted for a long time. Oh, and Tails/Spindash mode, which can be a novelty, though having the spindash makes it easier than it already is, which is stupid.

Introduction
I bought the Megadrive / Genesis collection and was surprised to see Sonic CD as an added bonus. Sonic CD was a game that I never got too far into when I was younger, not even past zone 2, not only because I was bad at videogames but because of the amazing soundtracks single flaw. (For those of you who don't know, the gameover music is horrifying to a young child.)

Now, keep in mind I love Sonic games old and new (excluding the new nintendo exclusives) meaning there's no bias, that and I didn't actually start playing Sonic games until I got Sonic Rush, I loved it and would love to see a steam remake.

I will not be spoiling the plot, though it is pretty simplistic however. Due to the fact that Sonic Games have never been plot heavy the plot will not effect this review.


The Review
THE MENU

Ok, first up (after the developer splash screens) you're greeted by a main menu, what's so great about this is the fact that you can do 2 things that made the game more enjoyable for me, from the main menu you can alternate between the Japanese/Europen and American soundtracks. I never got to experience my own regions soundtrack before due to the Gems Collection on the Playstation 2 sporting the american one. You can also switch between the spindash styles of Sonic 2 (and almost every game to follow) or Sonic CD's style. Choose the one that works for you.

GRAPHICS

The opening cutscene is a visual masterpiece full of action and compared to the original is astounding. The widescreen ajustment of the game also works wonders and makes the game more amazing to look at, the spritework is amazing too and it shows that Sonic Team has always been passionate about the Blue Blur. I could continue on the graphics but I'd just start repeating points.


GAMEPLAY

Did you like Sonic 2's fast gameplay? Good, CD takes that and amps it up! Sonic is fast and has no intention on stopping, when your on a roll, bouncing off everything and spinning through it all as you watch numbers in the hundreds pop up and add to your score is really satasfying.

To those of you who've never played a Sonic game, the general idea is run fast and jump into everything. Rolling will mow through enemies and so will a charged spindash attack.

Though in this game Sonic brings a new type of spindash to the table, the super peel out, it's faster but all you need to do is turn it into a roll and you get the destruction of a spindash and speed of the peel out. It kind of makes the peel out feel worthless.

Another mechanic is brought in, TIME TRAVEL. This game keeps it simple however, just go fast through a sign saying past" or "future" and you'll go that direction in time
